## Welcome

Welcome everybody to my fresh webpage. Every now and then I'll post short little code exercises that I think might be helpful for people out there. Most of this will be related to NetLogo and R and the combination of both tools.

In this first post, I will demonstrate how you can use R colorramps, such as the wonderful viridis colorramp, directly in your NetLogo models.


## Colorramps

The R package [Viridis](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/viridis/index.html) provides color palettes that are optimized to represent data. The colorramps are easier to read by those with colorblindness and can be easily distinguished when printed in grey scale.

I use viridis colorramps for many data visualization purposes every day. However, I also work quite a lot with NetLogo models and was always missing the possibilty to use nice color palettes for coloring the cells or turtles according to certain properties of these agents.

So I decided to implement a neat little function in NetLogo that can be copied to any of your NetLogo models. It will allow you to use the viridis color palettes and many other palettes directly within NetLogo.

## Extract color values from the viridis palettes

In order to implement the viridis colorramp into NetLogo, we first need to extract the RGB color values from the viridis palette. In the following code snippet, we use the [colormap](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/colormap/index.html) package to create a palette with RGB values.
Afterwards, we write the palette values to a *.txt file in a "NetLogo-friendly" format.

```{r, eval=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, results = 'hide'}
library(viridis)
library(colormap)
# Define length of palette. n > 300 doubles some colors
n <- 300
# Create a palette rgb dataframe
virpal <- colormap(colormap = colormaps$viridis, format = 'rgb', nshades = n)
# Remove alpha channel
virpal <- virpal[,-4]

# Write as file
sink("palette.txt")
cat("[")
for (i in 1:nrow(virpal))
{
  cat("[")
  cat(paste0(virpal[i,]))
  cat("]")
}
cat("]")
sink()
``` 

The colormap package supports many different colorramps, including additional viridis palettes, such as the magma or plasma palette. A complete list can be found [here](https://www.npmjs.com/package/colormap#options). In order to create output files for these colorramps, you only need to adjust the `colormaps$viridis` parameter within the `colormap` function call. For example, `colormap(colormap = colormaps$magma, format = 'rgb', nshades = n)` will report `n` values of the magma palette.

## Implementing the colorramp in NetLogo

Second, we need a function that scales our color palette to the variable values of agents.
This function works similar to the `scale-color` primitive of NetLogo. It will take 4 arguments. A string to select the palette that you want to use for coloring. This allows you to define multiple color palettes with different reporter functions (see examples in NetLogo example model at the buttom of this post).
The function will further take the variable value of the current agent. The remaining two values define the variable range. The function will then scale the variable range onto the range of the selected color palette and selects the item that corresponds to the variable value of the actual agent. By default, your `minvar` value will be smaller then the `maxvar` value. High values will then receive colors from the end of the list, whereas low values will receive colors from the beginning of the list. Similar to the `scale-color` primitive, you can revert the direction of the colorramp by switching the `minvar` and `maxvar` values (minvar > maxvar). 

```{}
to-report scale-colormap [palette var minvar maxvar]
  report item floor(((var - minvar) * (length(run-result (word "palette-" palette)) - 1)) / (maxvar - minvar)) run-result (word "palette-" palette)
end
```

Third, we may also want to define a function that allows us to pick a specific color from a palette.
This function also checks if the requested index value is available within the selected palette.

```{}
to-report colormap [palette palette_index]
  ifelse (palette_index >= length(run-result (word "palette-" palette)))
  [
    print (word "viridis color index invalid. Index maximum = " (length(run-result (word "palette-" palette)) - 1))
    report item 0 run-result (word "palette-" palette)
  ]
  [
    report item palette_index run-result (word "palette-" palette)
  ]
end
```

These functions can now be stored as a separate *.nls file. This file can then be included in any NetLogo model via the `__includes[]` primitive. 

## How to use the palettes

Using the `scale-colormap` functions works very similar to the `scale-color` primitive.
Assuming our turtles have a `turtles-own` variable `t_x`, we can use this variable to color the turtles according to these values using our functions. We first store the extremes of our variable distribution as local variables. We than ask all turtles to set their color, using the `scale-colormap` function and providing the chosen palette name, the name of the turtle variable and the corresponding extreme values.
```{}
;; Store extremevalues:
let xmin min [t_x] of turtles
let xmax max [t_x] of turtles

;; Set colors
ask turtles [set color scale-colormap "viridis" t_x xmin xmax]
```

Of course, we can do the same for patches:
```{}
;; Store extremevalues:
let xmin min [p_x] of patches
let xmax max [p_x] of patches

;; Set pcolors
ask patches [set pcolor scale-colormap "viridis" p_x xmin xmax]
```

As explained above, if you want to revert the colorramp, you can just switch the xmin and xmax values:
```{}
ask patches [set pcolor scale-colormap "viridis" p_x xmax xmin]
```


We can also use the `colormap` function to use one specific color from a palette. For example, if we want to color one random patch with the 42nd color of the viridis palette:
```{}
ask one-of patches [set pcolor colormap "viridis" 42]
```

## Complete NetLogo example including four palettes

You can download a NetLogo example model here:
[colormap.nlogo](data/colormap.nlogo);
[colormap.nls](data/colormap.nls)

The colormap.nls file contains the described functions above and can be included to any NetLogo model.
The colormap.nlogo model shows some examples of these functions in action. Please download both files, put them in the same folder and open the colormap.nlogo file to run the examples (NetLogo 6.1.0, but should work with older versions as well).
Of course you can edit the colormap.nls file and add more palette reporters of any palettes you wish to use.

Have fun coloring your agents, prettier than ever before and stay tuned for more NetLogo and R related content ;)
